days_plan.itin_title: AROUND THE WORLD IN 80 DAYS - IN THE FOOTSTEPS OF PHILEAS FOGG

visits.text: Fall in love with Aberaeron, a gorgeous Georgian coastal town on Cardigan Bay that ranks among Wales' most photogenic destinations. The colorful townhouses lining the harbor in shades of pink, blue, yellow and green create a rainbow of facades reflected in the calm waters below. This planned Regency town, built in the early 19th century, retains its elegant proportions and charming character.

Stroll along Aberaeron's picturesque harbor, where traditional fishing boats bob alongside pleasure craft against a backdrop of painted Georgian houses. The harbor promenade offers perfect vantage points for photography, especially during the magical golden hour when sunset light illuminates the colorful facades. Local seafood restaurants serve the day's catch in this authentic Welsh fishing community.

Discover New Quay, a seaside town just 20 minutes south along Cardigan Bay famous for its layered colorful houses cascading down to sandy beaches. This charming village, said to have inspired Dylan Thomas's Under Milk Wood, offers spectacular coastal scenery and excellent opportunities for dolphin watching in the bay. The tiered rows of brightly painted cottages create stunning compositions against the blue waters of the Irish Sea.

activities.text: Watch for bottlenose dolphins in Cardigan Bay, home to the largest resident population in the UK

days_plan.itin_title: Welsh Wonders: Castles, Coastlines and Celtic Charm

visits.text: Ride the historic Aberystwyth Cliff Railway, a charming funicular that has carried passengers up Constitution Hill since 1896. This Victorian engineering marvel offers one of the most spectacular viewpoints in Wales, revealing panoramic vistas over the town, Cardigan Bay and distant mountain peaks on clear days. The gentle ascent provides time to appreciate the beautifully maintained original carriages and mechanisms.

Explore Aberystwyth, a vibrant university town and seaside resort that serves as the cultural capital of Welsh-speaking Wales. The sweeping Victorian promenade curves around Cardigan Bay, lined with colorful hotels and guesthouses that have welcomed visitors since the railway age. The ruins of Aberystwyth Castle, perched on a headland, add historic drama to the coastal views.

Visit the National Library of Wales, one of only six copyright libraries in the UK, housing a vast collection of Welsh literature, manuscripts and historical records. The impressive Edwardian building on Penglais Hill overlooks the town and contains treasures including medieval Welsh poetry and the earliest surviving manuscript of the Mabinogion. The library's exhibitions bring Welsh culture and history vividly to life.

activities.text: Walk along the Victorian promenade and watch the sunset over Cardigan Bay from the seafront

visits.text: Journey to South Stack Lighthouse on the island of Anglesey, perched dramatically on a rocky islet at the northwestern tip of Wales. Built in 1809 to guide ships through the treacherous waters around Holy Island, this iconic lighthouse requires a descent of 400 steps to reach, rewarding visitors with spectacular clifftop scenery along the way. The lighthouse itself can be climbed for views across to Ireland and along the rugged Anglesey coastline.

Marvel at the dramatic sea cliffs surrounding South Stack, home to thousands of seabirds including guillemots, razorbills and, during the right season, adorable puffins that nest in the rocky crevices. The RSPB nature reserve offers walking trails along the clifftops with observation points for watching the incredible birdlife and the waves crashing against the rocks far below. The wild, windswept landscape represents Wales at its most dramatically beautiful.

Explore Anglesey, the largest island in Wales, connected to the mainland by two bridges including Thomas Telford's historic suspension bridge. Beaumaris Castle, another of Edward I's mighty fortresses, represents the most technically perfect medieval castle in Britain, while the island's beaches, prehistoric sites and charming villages reward further exploration. The island's Welsh name, Ynys Môn, reflects its importance as the heartland of Welsh language and culture.

activities.text: Visit during spring or early summer for the chance to spot puffins nesting on the cliffs

visits.text: Enter the Cairngorms National Park, Britain's largest national park, where ancient Caledonian pine forests, wild mountains and crystal-clear lochs create landscapes of extraordinary natural beauty. This wilderness in the heart of the Scottish Highlands is home to red squirrels, red deer, golden eagles and the elusive Scottish wildcat. The range of outdoor activities available here, from gentle riverside walks to challenging mountain climbs, caters to every level of adventurer.

Explore Aviemore, the adventure capital of the Cairngorms, where outdoor enthusiasts gather to pursue activities ranging from mountain biking and hiking to skiing and wildlife safaris. The town sits at the heart of the Spey Valley, surrounded by ancient forests, rushing rivers and majestic peaks. Companies offer everything from zip-lining and white water rafting to wildlife watching and wild swimming in the clear mountain waters.

Ride the Strathspey Railway, a heritage steam train that chugs through beautiful Highland scenery from Aviemore to Broomhill. This nostalgic journey in Victorian carriages offers lunch or afternoon tea while passing through landscapes of forest, moorland and mountains. The gentle pace allows time to absorb the beauty of Speyside and watch for the abundant wildlife that makes this area special.

Walk around Loch an Eilein in the ancient Rothiemurchus Forest, one of the most beautiful lochs in Scotland with a ruined castle on its island. The circular walk through Caledonian pine forest, home to red squirrels and crested tits, offers constantly changing views of the loch and surrounding mountains. The Loch an Eilein art gallery showcases local artists' works inspired by this magical landscape.

activities.text: Visit the RZSS Highland Wildlife Park near Kingussie to see polar bears, Amur tigers and Scottish wildlife including wolves and wildcats

visits.text: Explore the wild expanses of Bodmin Moor, a vast inland moorland of granite outcrops and barren pastures that stands apart from Cornwall's famous coastline. This ancient landscape is recognized as one of the finest locations in Europe for Neolithic and Bronze Age monuments, with stone circles, standing stones and burial chambers scattered across the heather-covered hills. The mysterious King Arthur's Hall, a megalithic ceremonial site, is among the most famous prehistoric remains.

Discover the fascinating geological history of this wild place, where weathered tors rise from the moorland like sentinels from another age. The landscape has inspired legends and folklore for millennia, from tales of the Beast of Bodmin to Arthurian mythology. Walking trails crisscross the moor, offering solitude and dramatic scenery far removed from the coastal crowds.

visits.text: Discover Bournemouth, the largest seaside town in Dorset and voted the happiest place in the UK, where award-winning Blue Flag beaches stretch for miles beneath dramatic cliffs. This vibrant coastal resort boasts Green Flag gardens that make up an impressive 20% of the entire town, creating a unique blend of seaside excitement and natural tranquility. The Victorian pier, colorful beach huts and golden sands have drawn visitors since the town's founding in the 19th century.

Stroll through Bournemouth's magnificent gardens, starting with the Lower, Central and Upper Gardens in the heart of town, home to plants and trees from across the globe. The Alum Chine Tropical Gardens transport visitors to the Mediterranean with their exotic plantings, while Pinecliff Gardens offer Spanish-style landscapes overlooking the sea. Stour Valley provides a peaceful village atmosphere with the calming sounds of the flowing River Stour.

Visit the Russell-Cotes Art Gallery and Museum, a stunning Victorian mansion perched on the East Cliff that houses an eclectic collection of Victorian and Edwardian art and artifacts. The building itself is a work of art, with ornate interiors and breathtaking views across the bay. Pay your respects at St Peter's Church, the final resting place of Frankenstein author Mary Shelley, whose grave draws literary pilgrims from around the world.

activities.text: Walk from Bournemouth Pier to Boscombe Pier, discovering historical displays showing how seaside life has evolved over the decades

visits.text: Marvel at Caernarfon Castle, the mightiest of Edward I's Welsh fortresses and a UNESCO World Heritage site that has dominated this strategic spot for over 700 years. The castle's unique polygonal towers and banded masonry were deliberately designed to echo the walls of Constantinople, emphasizing Edward's imperial ambitions. This is where the investiture of Princes of Wales has taken place since 1911, most recently for Prince Charles in 1969.

Climb the castle's towers for spectacular views over the Menai Strait, the town's slate rooftops, and the mountains of Snowdonia rising dramatically to the east. The Eagle Tower, the largest of the castle's distinctive towers, offers the most impressive panorama and contains exhibitions on the castle's history and the Welsh princes it was built to suppress. The castle walls, remarkably intact after seven centuries, allow visitors to walk above the medieval town.

Explore the charming town of Caernarfon, where the castle serves as a dramatic backdrop to narrow streets lined with independent shops, cafes and traditional Welsh pubs. The town walls, largely intact, connect to the castle and offer elevated walks with views over the harbor where boats depart for trips along the Menai Strait. The Welsh language thrives here, giving visitors an authentic taste of Welsh culture and heritage.

activities.text: Photograph the castle from the town streets where medieval towers frame views of shops and daily Welsh life

visits.text: Swim in the magical Fairy Pools, a series of crystal-clear waterfalls and pools at the foot of the Black Cuillins that have become one of Scotland's most beloved wild swimming spots. The turquoise waters, filtered through ancient rocks, are cold but invigorating, while the mountain backdrop creates scenes of extraordinary natural beauty. Even if you don't brave the water, the walk along the River Brittle through this enchanted landscape is unforgettable.

Visit Dunvegan Castle & Gardens, the oldest continuously inhabited castle in Scotland and ancestral home of the Chiefs of Clan MacLeod for over 800 years. The castle houses precious clan relics including the legendary Fairy Flag, believed to have magical powers to save the clan in times of peril. The beautiful gardens, boat trips to see the local seal colony, and fascinating family history make this a highlight of any Skye visit.

Tour the Talisker Distillery in Carbost, the oldest working distillery on the Isle of Skye, producing a distinctive peaty single malt whisky since 1830. The distillery's remote location on the shores of Loch Harport, surrounded by the dramatic Cuillin mountains, contributes to the unique character of this beloved whisky. The new tasting room offers the chance to sample the full range and learn about the craft that has made Talisker famous worldwide.

activities.text: Take a seal-spotting boat trip from Dunvegan Castle to see the resident colony basking on the rocks

Explore Cardiff, the vibrant capital of Wales, where centuries of history blend seamlessly with modern Welsh culture. Cardiff Castle stands at the heart of the city, its medieval keep and Victorian Gothic apartments revealing layers of history from Roman times to the extravagant 19th-century makeover by the Marquess of Bute. The castle's fairy-tale towers and opulent interiors decorated with gold leaf, murals and intricate carvings create one of Britain's most remarkable heritage sites.

Wander through Cardiff's beautiful Victorian and Edwardian arcades, elegant covered shopping passages that have served the city for over a century. These ornate galleries with their independent boutiques, vintage shops and cozy cafes represent some of the finest examples of arcade architecture in Britain. The intricate ironwork, glass roofs and decorative tiles transport visitors back to the golden age of retail.

Marvel at the Wales Millennium Centre in Cardiff Bay, a stunning architectural masterpiece that serves as the home of Welsh national opera, ballet and theatre. The distinctive bronze-colored steel and slate facade features a poetic inscription visible from across the bay, while the interior showcases exceptional acoustics and contemporary Welsh design. Cardiff Bay itself offers waterfront dining, boat tours and the impressive Senedd building housing the Welsh Parliament.

Visit Castell Coch, the fairy-tale red castle perched in woodland on the northern outskirts of Cardiff, rebuilt in Victorian Gothic fantasy style by the same architect who transformed Cardiff Castle. The conical towers rising above the beech forest create a scene straight from a medieval romance, while the lavish interiors feature hand-painted walls and ceilings inspired by medieval manuscripts. Bute Park, stretching from the castle to the bay, offers peaceful green spaces along the River Taff.

visits.text: Cycle to Hengistbury Head, a scenic headland and nature reserve of international importance for both its wildlife and archaeological excavations. This dramatic promontory offers sweeping views along the coast while harboring rare habitats that support diverse plant and animal species. The heathland, dunes and coastal habitats create a mosaic of environments perfect for nature walks and birdwatching.

Continue along the coast to Mudeford Sandbank, a remarkable sandspit separating Hengistbury Head from Christchurch that is covered with colorful beach huts commanding extraordinary prices. These much-coveted huts, some selling for over £350,000 despite lacking running water, offer views across to the Isle of Wight from an area unspoiled by development. The sandbank's remote character and pristine beaches make it one of Dorset's most desirable coastal locations.

Explore historic Christchurch, accessible by ferry from Mudeford Sandbank, where the magnificent Priory has stood since the 11th century, one of few monasteries to survive Henry VIII's dissolution. The ruins of the 12th-century castle and Constable's House speak to the town's medieval importance, while climbing the 176-step tower rewards visitors with panoramic views across the town and harbor. This charming market town perfectly blends historic architecture with riverside tranquility.

activities.text: Rent a bicycle and ride alongside the seafront, admiring the iconic colorful beach huts that line the coast

visits.text: Explore Conwy Castle, one of the finest medieval fortresses in Europe and a masterpiece of 13th-century military architecture that dominates this historic walled town. Built by Edward I between 1283 and 1289, the castle retains all eight of its massive towers and much of its curtain wall, creating an atmospheric monument that feels authentically medieval rather than over-restored. The combination of ruined sections and intact towers gives visitors a genuine sense of stepping back through centuries of history.

Climb the castle towers for extraordinary views over the harbor, the medieval town, and Snowdonia's peaks rising in the distance. The vantage point allows photography across to other towers, creating dramatic landscape shots that appear almost drone-captured. On sunny days, the light plays across the ancient stones while boats bob in the harbor below, creating scenes of timeless beauty.

Walk the complete circuit of Conwy's medieval town walls, the most complete in Britain, which protected the English settlement Edward I created alongside his castle. The walls stretch for over three-quarters of a mile, studded with 21 towers and offering elevated views over the town's slate rooftops, the castle and the estuary. The Smallest House in Great Britain, a tiny red fisherman's cottage on the quay, adds a quirky footnote to the town's history.

activities.text: Arrive early when the castle opens to photograph the towers without other visitors for the most dramatic shots

days_plan.itin_title: Welsh Wonders: Castles, Coastlines and Celtic Charm

visits.text: Stand among the dramatic ruins of Corfe Castle, built by William the Conqueror in the 11th century and now one of England's most evocative castle ruins. The shattered towers and crumbling walls, deliberately destroyed during the English Civil War, rise from a steep hill creating silhouettes that are especially magical at sunset when the light passes through the ancient stonework. The neighboring village was literally built from stones taken from the castle, creating an intimate connection between fortress and community.

Climb the neighboring hill for panoramic views of the castle ruins, a moderately challenging hike that rewards visitors with one of Dorset's most photographed vistas. The dramatic profile of the ruined towers against the Purbeck countryside has inspired artists and photographers for centuries. Group tours of the castle ruins reveal the turbulent history of this fortress that withstood sieges and witnessed royal murders.

Board the Swanage Railway for a nostalgic journey through 12 miles of beautiful Purbeck countryside aboard a historic steam locomotive. This heritage railway, lovingly restored by volunteers, offers a unique perspective on the landscape as it winds through valleys and past villages. The gentle pace and romantic atmosphere of steam travel create a memorable experience that complements the castle visit perfectly.

activities.text: Time your castle visit for sunset to see the golden light illuminating the ancient ruins

visits.text: Wander through Sculpture by the Lakes, a hidden gem featuring over 30 monumental sculptures by celebrated British artist Simon Gudgeon set around a peaceful lake near Dorchester. This unique outdoor gallery combines the beauty of the Dorset countryside with stunning contemporary art, where giant bronze sculptures emerge from woodlands and reflect in still waters. The precision and artistry of these large-scale works create a truly moving experience for visitors of all ages.

Explore Kingston Lacy, a National Trust treasure near Wimborne that houses one of the most significant art collections in Britain within a stunning 17th-century mansion. The house was transformed into a Venetian-style palace by William John Bankes, an avid collector who filled the rooms with Old Master paintings and artifacts from around the world, including a remarkable collection of Egyptian antiquities in the basement. The extensive grounds feature beautiful Japanese gardens, monumental cedar trees and perfect picnic spots.

Discover the mansion's extraordinary interiors, where Spanish leather-hung walls, Venetian ceilings and an impressive collection of paintings by Rubens, Van Dyck and other masters create rooms of remarkable beauty and historical significance. William Bankes' obsessive collecting and transformative vision created one of England's most remarkable country house interiors. The Egyptian collection, acquired during Bankes' extensive travels, includes an obelisk that predates many of the British Museum's treasures.

activities.text: Pack a picnic to enjoy in the extensive grounds of Kingston Lacy beneath the magnificent cedar trees

visits.text: Discover the legendary waters of Loch Ness, Scotland's most famous lake whose dark, peat-stained depths have fueled tales of a prehistoric monster since 565 CE. The 23-mile-long loch contains more fresh water than all the lakes in England and Wales combined, plunging to depths of over 230 meters where Nessie supposedly lurks. Whether you believe in the monster or not, the brooding atmosphere of this great glen surrounded by forested hillsides creates an undeniably mysterious setting.

Explore the atmospheric ruins of Urquhart Castle, dramatically positioned on a promontory jutting into Loch Ness with commanding views up and down the great glen. This 13th-century fortress witnessed 500 years of Scottish history, enduring sieges, battles and eventually deliberate destruction to prevent it falling into Jacobite hands. The Grant Tower offers spectacular views across the loch, and it's no surprise this is one of the prime Nessie-spotting locations.

Visit the Loch Ness Centre & Exhibition to delve into the fascinating history of monster sightings, scientific expeditions and the enduring mystery that has captivated the world. Interactive displays examine the evidence, from grainy photographs to sonar readings, while exploring the geological and natural history of this remarkable body of water. The story of Marmaduke Wetherell's famous hoaxed footprints reminds visitors that not everything is as it seems in these mysterious waters.

activities.text: Take a boat cruise across the dark waters of Loch Ness, keeping your camera ready for any unusual disturbances

visits.text: Glenfinnan Viaduct viewpoint (Harry Potter/Jacobite rails)
Glenfinnan Monument & lochside

Ride the legendary Jacobite Steam Train across the Glenfinnan Viaduct, made famous worldwide as the Hogwarts Express in the Harry Potter films. This 84-mile journey through some of the most dramatic scenery in the Scottish Highlands takes two hours each way, crossing 21 arches of the iconic viaduct and passing silvery beaches before reaching the deepest seawater loch in Europe. The vintage carriages and working steam locomotive create an authentic experience of golden-age rail travel.

Stand at the Glenfinnan Monument, commemorating the spot where Bonnie Prince Charlie raised his standard in 1745 to begin the Jacobite Rising that would end in tragedy at Culloden. The tower, crowned by a kilted Highlander, stands at the head of Loch Shiel against a backdrop of mountains that have witnessed centuries of Scottish history. The visitor centre tells the story of the '45 and the Highland clans who rallied to the Stuart cause.

Pay respects at the Commando Memorial near Spean Bridge, a powerful bronze sculpture overlooking the training grounds where thousands of Allied commandos prepared for the most dangerous operations of World War II. The three commandos in full battle dress stand eternally vigilant, their gaze fixed on Ben Nevis, honoring those who trained here and the many who never returned. The panoramic views across the Great Glen add to the solemnity of this moving memorial.

Conquer Ben Nevis, the highest mountain in the British Isles at 1,345 meters, whose misty summit has challenged and rewarded over 100,000 hikers every year. The Mountain Track (or Tourist Path) offers a relentless but achievable climb with spectacular views unfolding as you ascend above the clouds. Standing on the roof of Britain, with Scotland spread out beneath you, creates a sense of achievement that will stay with you forever.

For a gentler alternative, hike to the stunning Steall Waterfall in Glen Nevis, one of Scotland's highest waterfalls cascading 120 meters into a dramatic mountain amphitheater. The walk through the Nevis Gorge, following the rushing river beneath towering cliffs, is spectacular in its own right. A wire rope bridge adds a touch of adventure to the crossing for those brave enough to attempt it.

Explore Fort William, the 'Outdoor Capital of the UK', which serves as the gateway to some of Scotland's finest mountain landscapes and adventure activities. The town offers excellent shops for outdoor gear, traditional pubs serving hearty Highland fare, and the West Highland Museum with its fascinating collection of Jacobite artifacts. The views across Loch Linnhe to the mountains beyond remind visitors why this area has attracted adventurers for centuries.

visits.text: Drive through the dramatic Glen Coe, where magnificent mountains and deep valleys create possibly the most spectacular scenery in all of Scotland. The A82 connects one end to the other in just 20 minutes, but you could spend a whole day taking in the sights and hiking the trails of this legendary glen. The brooding atmosphere recalls the infamous Massacre of Glencoe in 1692, when members of Clan MacDonald were slaughtered by government troops.

Stop at the Three Sisters Viewpoint for the classic photograph of Bidean nam Bian's dramatic peaks towering above the glen. The three great ridges plunging down to the valley floor create one of Scotland's most recognizable mountain scenes. Information boards explain the geology and history of this ancient landscape carved by ice and time.

Hike up to the Hidden Valley (Coire Gabhail), a secret hanging valley where the MacDonalds once hid their stolen cattle from raiding parties. The steep climb through a boulder-strewn gorge opens into a magical flat-bottomed valley surrounded by towering peaks, invisible from the glen below. This hidden world feels like discovering Scotland's best-kept secret, a place untouched by time.

activities.text: End the day at the Clachaig Inn, an atmospheric hikers' pub that has warmed weary travelers for over 300 years

days_plan.itin_title: Scottish Highlands Grand Tour: Castles, Lochs and Wild Landscapes

visits.text: Marvel at Dunrobin Castle, the largest house in the Scottish Highlands with 189 rooms connected by a maze of corridors and crowned with fairy-tale French-style turrets. This magnificent stately home, seat of the Earls and Dukes of Sutherland since the 13th century, combines Scottish baronial architecture with the elegance of a Loire château. The formal gardens, modeled on Versailles, sweep down to the sea, and daily falconry displays showcase eagles, hawks and owls in flight.

Explore the castle's opulent interiors, where grand reception rooms display fine furniture, paintings and hunting trophies accumulated over seven centuries of aristocratic occupation. The museum houses an eclectic collection including Pictish stones, natural history specimens and artifacts from around the world. The contrast between the fairy-tale exterior and the lived-in warmth of the interior reveals the continuing story of one of Scotland's great noble families.

Journey to John O'Groats, the most northerly settlement on mainland Britain, where a famous signpost marks the distance to Land's End 874 miles to the south. This iconic location at the tip of Scotland offers views across the Pentland Firth to the Orkney Islands, and serves as the departure point for ferries to these ancient Norse territories. The wild coastline and sense of having reached the edge of the world makes this a quintessential Scottish experience.

activities.text: Watch the spectacular falconry display in Dunrobin's gardens, featuring golden eagles and other birds of prey

visits.text: Stand in awe before Harlech Castle, a magnificent 13th-century fortress built by King Edward I that dominates the landscape from its dramatic clifftop position overlooking Tremadog Bay. This UNESCO World Heritage site, one of the finest examples of late 13th-century military architecture in Europe, inspired the famous Welsh anthem 'Men of Harlech.' The castle's massive walls and towers seem to grow from the rocky outcrop itself, creating an unforgettable silhouette against sea and mountain.

Explore the castle's impressive gatehouse, one of the strongest built during the medieval period, designed to withstand the most determined siege. The views from the battlements stretch across to the Llŷn Peninsula, along the coast to the mountains of Snowdonia, and on clear days all the way to Ireland. The atmospheric ruins evoke centuries of Welsh history, from Edward's conquest to Owain Glyndŵr's legendary siege.

Discover Harlech's beautiful beach, a vast expanse of golden sand stretching below the castle cliffs that offers a dramatic contrast to the fortress above. The beach, backed by dunes and with the castle as a constant backdrop, provides unique photographic opportunities combining medieval architecture with natural beauty. The small town of Harlech itself retains a quiet Welsh character, with traditional shops and welcoming local pubs.

activities.text: Capture the perfect photograph of the castle from the road below, framing it against the Snowdonia mountains

days_plan.itin_title: LONDON IN 3 DAYS: WESTMINSTER, MUSEUMS, TOWER & ICONIC DISTRICTS

visits.text: Photograph Kilchurn Castle from the shores of Loch Awe, one of Scotland's most romantic ruins jutting out on a promontory with heather-strewn slopes rising behind. On still days, the castle's reflection shimmers perfectly in the water, creating images that have graced countless calendars and postcards. Built in the 15th century by Sir Colin Campbell, the castle now stands as a picturesque reminder of the powerful clan that once controlled these lands.

Explore Inveraray, an interesting Georgian planned town on the edge of Loch Fyne whose uniform white-painted facades create a harmonious streetscape. The high street offers eclectic shops, galleries and cute cafes, including the famous Loch Fyne Whiskies with its extraordinary selection. The War Memorial provides a great spot to take in views across Loch Fyne to the hills beyond.

Visit Inveraray Castle, the fairy-tale home of the Duke and Duchess of Argyle, whose turrets and towers rise above magnificent landscaped grounds. This grand seat of Clan Campbell has welcomed visitors for generations with its impressive state rooms, extensive armory and beautiful gardens. The castle's combination of medieval romance and aristocratic elegance epitomizes the grand houses of the Scottish Highlands.

Begin your Highland adventure in Inverness, the cultural capital of the Scottish Highlands, where the River Ness flows through this vibrant city steeped in history. Climb to the top of Inverness Castle for the Castle Viewpoint, offering a spectacular 360-degree panorama over the surrounding mountains, lochs and the city below. This modern red sandstone castle serves as a gateway to understanding the dramatic landscape you're about to explore.

Stand on the haunting grounds of Culloden Battlefield, the site of the final Jacobite Rising in 1746 where Bonnie Prince Charlie's hopes of reclaiming the British throne were crushed in less than an hour. The visitor centre's interactive exhibition brings this pivotal moment in Scottish history vividly to life, while memorial stones mark the mass graves of the fallen Highland clans. Walking these windswept moors, you can almost hear the clash of swords and the cries of battle that changed Scotland forever.

Explore Fort George, one of the most outstanding artillery fortifications in Europe, built following the Jacobite defeat to ensure Highland rebellion could never rise again. Step onto the main rampart for commanding views across the Moray Firth, visit the grand magazine housing an impressive collection of weaponry, and discover the touching dog cemetery where officers' beloved pets were laid to rest. This massive military complex remains virtually unchanged since the 18th century.

visits.text: Discover Llandudno, Wales' largest seaside resort, a beautifully preserved Victorian town nestled between two limestone headlands on the North Wales coast. The elegant sweep of the promenade, lined with pastel-painted hotels and guest houses, curves around the bay with the Great Orme rising dramatically at its northern end. This classic British seaside town has maintained its Victorian character while offering modern attractions.

Ride the Great Orme Tramway, Britain's only cable-hauled street tramway, which has carried passengers up the headland since 1902. The vintage trams climb through residential streets before emerging onto the open hillside with spectacular views unfolding across the bay, town and mountains beyond. At the summit, panoramic vistas stretch across the Irish Sea to the Isle of Man on clear days.

Take the Llandudno Cable Cars for a different perspective on the Great Orme's dramatic landscapes and the town spread out below. The longest passenger cable car system in Britain glides over limestone grasslands grazed by wild Kashmir goats, descendants of a herd gifted by the Shah of Persia in 1837. The summit offers walking trails, an ancient copper mine dating back 4,000 years, and endless views over sea and shore.

activities.text: Walk or drive to the summit of the Great Orme for sunset views over the Irish Sea and Snowdonia mountains

days_plan.itin_title: Welsh Wonders: Castles, Coastlines and Celtic Charm

visits.text: Enter the magical landscape of Assynt, one of the last great wildernesses of Europe where 'island mountains' rise dramatically from a crinkled carpet of lochs, heather and ancient rock. This remote corner of the Scottish Highlands, rarely visited by tourists, offers some of the most unique scenery in Britain. The Torridonian sandstone peaks, over 1 billion years old, create otherworldly silhouettes against the ever-changing Highland sky.

Hike to the summit of Stac Pollaidh, one of Assynt's most distinctive mountains, whose shattered sandstone pinnacles create a dramatic ridgeline above the surrounding moorland. The relatively short but steep climb rewards hikers with 360-degree views encompassing dozens of lochs, the Summer Isles in the distance, and neighboring peaks including Suilven and Cul Mor. This is landscape photography at its finest, with compositions that seem almost too dramatic to be real.

Discover the powder-white beaches of Assynt, where turquoise waters lap against sand so fine and white it rivals any Caribbean shore. Clachtoll and Achmelvich beaches offer stunning coastal scenery backed by craggy rocks and wildflower meadows, while the Summer Isles shimmer on the horizon. These hidden gems of the Scottish coast reward those who venture off the beaten path with unforgettable natural beauty.

activities.text: Visit the romantic ruins of Ardvreck Castle on the shores of Loch Assynt, once a stronghold of the MacLeod clan

visits.text: Cross the ancient causeway to St Michael's Mount, Cornwall's own version of France's famous Mont Saint-Michel and one of the most iconic landmarks in England. This tidal island, crowned by a medieval castle and church, has been a site of pilgrimage since Benedictine monks constructed the first church here in 1135. The causeway connecting the island to the mainland at Marazion becomes submerged at high tide, adding an element of adventure to every visit.

Explore the castle atop St Michael's Mount, which evolved from a monastery into a fortress and now serves as a family home while welcoming visitors to its historic rooms and magnificent gardens. The views from the island across Mount's Bay to the Cornish coast are spectacular, encompassing miles of golden beaches and dramatic headlands. The subtropical gardens, clinging to the rocky slopes, feature exotic plants that thrive in the mild Cornish climate.

Stroll through Marazion, the charming mainland town that serves as the gateway to St Michael's Mount and offers excellent views of the island from its beaches and promenade. This historic settlement claims to be one of the oldest chartered towns in Britain, with a history stretching back to the Bronze Age. The traditional pubs and independent shops provide a pleasant base for exploring this corner of Cornwall.

activities.text: Time your visit to cross the causeway on foot at low tide for the full pilgrimage experience

days_plan.itin_title: Cornwall Coastal Treasures: Castles, Coves and Celtic Heritage

visits.text: Discover Mevagissey, the postcard-perfect Cornish fishing village where colorful cottages and working boats crowd around a picturesque double harbor. This authentic fishing community has retained its traditional character while offering excellent opportunities to enjoy the freshest seafood in charming waterfront settings. The narrow lanes climbing up from the harbor reveal independent shops, galleries and glimpses of the fishing heritage that has sustained this village for centuries.

Stroll along the harbor walls watching fishermen land their catch and preparing boats for the next tide, a scene that has changed little over generations. The village's sheltered position and thriving fishing fleet made it a prosperous community, and the handsome merchants' houses climbing the hillside reflect this maritime wealth. Local boat trips offer the chance to explore the coastline from the water and spot the marine wildlife that thrives in these clear Cornish waters.

visits.text: Step into the medieval world of Cawdor Castle, forever linked to Shakespeare's Macbeth and still home to the Cawdor family after 600 years. The 14th-century tower house, built around a legendary holly tree, is surrounded by three magnificent gardens and extensive nature trails through ancient woodland. The castle's atmospheric rooms are filled with fascinating artifacts, family portraits and the accumulated treasures of centuries of aristocratic Scottish life.

Explore Brodie Castle, a Z-plan tower house that has been home to the Brodie clan for over 400 years, just 4 miles from Forres. The castle houses an impressive collection of paintings, French furniture and Chinese porcelain, while the Playful Garden delights families with its imaginative design. Special events throughout the year bring the castle and its extensive grounds to life with seasonal celebrations.

Discover the dramatic ruins of Ruthven Barracks near Kingussie, standing stark against the Highland sky as a reminder of the government's attempts to control the Highlands after the 1715 Jacobite Rising. These imposing barracks were captured and burned by Bonnie Prince Charlie's retreating army in 1746, and today the gaunt walls and empty windows create one of Scotland's most evocative historic sites. The views across Strathspey from this elevated position are spectacular.

activities.text: Walk through Cawdor Castle's three distinct gardens: the Walled Garden, Flower Garden and Wild Garden

visits.text: Ride the waves at Newquay, England's undisputed surf capital, where Atlantic swells create some of the best surfing conditions in Britain. Whether you're an experienced surfer or complete beginner, numerous surf schools and board rental shops cater to all abilities on the town's many beaches. The surf culture has shaped Newquay's laid-back character and vibrant nightlife, making it a favorite destination for active visitors.

Explore the dramatic coastline around Newquay, where low-slung cliffs and hidden coves create perfect conditions for coasteering adventures combining climbing, jumping and swimming. Fistral Beach, consistently ranked among the best surf beaches in Europe, hosts international competitions that draw the world's top surfers. The surrounding headlands offer spectacular walking with views along the coast in both directions.

Discover the family-friendly attractions around Newquay, including the excellent zoo and several National Trust manor houses set in the rolling countryside slightly inland. As one of the larger towns in Cornwall, Newquay offers a wider range of accommodation, restaurants and entertainment than smaller coastal villages. The permanent population of 20,000 can multiply five times during peak summer season, a testament to the town's enduring popularity.

visits.text: Journey to Land's End, the most westerly point of mainland England, where dramatic cliffs plunge into the Atlantic Ocean and the views extend to the Isles of Scilly on clear days. This legendary location has captivated visitors since ancient times; even the Greeks knew this place, naming it 'Belerion' meaning 'place of the sun.' The famous signpost marking distances to faraway destinations has become an iconic photo opportunity for visitors from around the world.

Experience the Minack Theatre, one of the most unique and spectacular performance venues in the world, carved into the clifftop overlooking Porthcurno Bay. Nearly 100 years ago, Rowena Cade began chiseling this remarkable amphitheatre out of the granite cliff face, creating an open-air stage with the Atlantic Ocean as its backdrop. Even when no performances are scheduled, visiting the theatre to admire its ingenious design and magnificent setting is worthwhile.

Explore the golden sands of Porthcurno Beach, consistently rated among the finest beaches in the UK, where turquoise waters lap against dramatic cliffs. The beach's sheltered position and crystal-clear waters make it popular for swimming, while the surrounding cliffs offer excellent walking. The nearby Telegraph Museum tells the fascinating story of the undersea cables that once connected Britain to the world from this remote Cornish cove.

visits.text: Plockton (coastal village, palm trees & bay)
Eilean Donan Castle (exteriors and viewpoints)

Fall in love with Plockton, often called the 'Jewel of the Highlands', a picture-perfect village where palm trees line the waterfront thanks to the warming influence of the Gulf Stream. This sheltered bay on Loch Carron is framed by breathtaking landscapes of coral beaches, tiny islands and castle-crowned hills stretching into the distance. The stone cottages lining the harbor, bobbing yachts and resident seals create scenes of timeless Scottish beauty.

Kayak or take a boat trip from Plockton's harbor to spot the colony of grey seals that bask on the nearby rocks. The calm waters of the bay provide perfect conditions for paddling, while the surrounding mountains create a dramatic amphitheater of scenery. Evening light transforms the village into a photographer's paradise, with reflections shimmering across the still waters.

Drive the legendary Bealach na Bà near Applecross, one of the highest roads in Britain with gradients of up to 20% and hairpin bends that make it a legendary driving challenge. The views from the summit across to the Isle of Skye and the Outer Hebrides are simply breathtaking on a clear day. This ancient cattle drovers' pass offers an authentic taste of Highland adventure that will have your heart racing.

activities.text: Walking access to islets at low tide (depending on tide times)
End the day in one of Plockton's atmospheric pubs, enjoying fresh fish and local ales with views across the bay

days_plan.itin_title: GRAND TOUR OF ENGLAND: FROM CORNWALL TO THE NORTHERN LAKES
SOUTHWEST ENGLAND: CORNWALL, DEVON AND WILD COASTS

visits.text: Explore Poole, home to the largest natural harbor in Europe, where centuries of maritime history blend with modern watersports and a thriving yachting scene. The historic quay bustles with boat trips, waterfront restaurants and the departure point for ferries to Brownsea Island. This ancient port has welcomed traders and travelers since Roman times, and its sheltered waters now attract paddleboarders, kitesurfers and sailors from across Britain.

Discover Sandbanks, the exclusive peninsula at the entrance to Poole Harbour that reportedly has one of the highest land values by area in the world. This millionaires' playground features stunning beaches backed by some of Britain's most expensive properties, yet the golden sands and clear waters remain accessible to all visitors. The views across to Brownsea Island and the dramatic cliffs of the Jurassic Coast make this one of Dorset's most scenic spots.

Take a boat tour from Poole to see Old Harry Rocks, the dramatic chalk stacks that mark the eastern end of the UNESCO World Heritage Jurassic Coast. These gleaming white pillars rising from the turquoise sea have been sculpted by millennia of wind and waves, creating one of England's most iconic coastal landmarks. The boat trip offers unique perspectives on the cliffs and coastline impossible to appreciate from land.

activities.text: Try paddleboarding or kitesurfing in the sheltered waters of Europe's largest natural harbor

days_plan.itin_title: Dorset's Jurassic Wonders: Cliffs, Castles and Coastal Charm

visits.text: Fall in love with Port Isaac, a quintessential Cornish fishing village snuggled around a tiny harbor in North Cornwall. A cluster of whitewashed and slate-fronted cottages tumble down steep lanes to the pocket-sized beach where colorful fishing boats bob at their moorings. The village's protected harbor has preserved its historic character, even as the fishing industry that built it has declined, creating one of the most photogenic destinations in Cornwall.

Explore Port Isaac's narrow lanes and atmospheric corners that have featured in numerous film and television productions, including the popular Doc Martin series. The village's history is intimately tied to fishing, an industry that peaked here in the early 19th century when pilchards were exported across Europe. Today, traditional fishing continues alongside a thriving tourism industry, with crab and lobster pots stacked on the quay.

Walk the spectacular stretch of the South West Coast Path connecting Port Isaac to Tintagel, a 10-mile route that takes in dramatic rock formations and lesser-visited beaches. This section of Cornwall's coastline is particularly spectacular in spring when wildflowers carpet the clifftops, adding splashes of color to the green headlands. The walking offers constantly changing perspectives on the rugged North Cornwall coast.

activities.text: Watch for the Fisherman's Friends, the local sea shanty group who sometimes perform on the harbor's Platt

days_plan.itin_title: Cornwall Coastal Treasures: Castles, Coves and Celtic Heritage

visits.text: Discover the Lizard Peninsula, one of the most spectacular stretches of coastline in all of England and a personal favorite for many visitors to Cornwall. Thanks to limited road access and minimal development, this southernmost point of mainland Britain retains an unspoiled character and get-away-from-it-all atmosphere that feels increasingly rare. The peninsula's serpentine rock creates distinctive green and red coloring in the cliffs and has been worked by local craftspeople for centuries.

Visit the Cornish Seal Sanctuary, where injured and orphaned seals receive treatment and rehabilitation before being released back into the wild. Unlike typical zoo attractions, this facility focuses primarily on rescue and recovery, giving visitors the opportunity to see these charismatic marine mammals while supporting important conservation work. The sanctuary offers insight into the challenges facing Cornwall's seal population and the dedicated efforts to protect them.

Explore the idyllic fishing villages of Coverack and Cadgwith, where thatched cottages cluster around tiny harbors that have changed little over generations. These authentic communities offer perfect spots to enjoy fish and chips while watching the fishing boats come and go. The dramatic coastal scenery surrounding these villages, with towering cliffs and hidden coves, rewards those who venture off the main tourist routes.

Marvel at Kynance Cove, often considered one of the most beautiful beaches in Cornwall with its turquoise waters, white sand and dramatic serpentine rock formations. This stunning cove, owned by the National Trust, offers excellent swimming when conditions allow and spectacular photography opportunities year-round. The unique geology creates islands and caves that are revealed at low tide, adding an element of exploration to any visit.

activities.text: Walk the South West Coast Path along the Lizard's dramatic clifftops with views toward Lizard Point

days_plan.itin_title: Cornwall Coastal Treasures: Castles, Coves and Celtic Heritage

visits.text: Explore the Isle of Portland, the most southerly point of Dorset, a limestone peninsula joined to the mainland by Chesil Beach and steeped in military history. The biggest man-made harbor in the world, of critical importance during both World Wars, speaks to Portland's strategic significance, while today the island offers tranquility, abundant wildlife and dramatic coastal scenery. The distinctive Portland stone quarried here has been used to construct some of Britain's finest buildings, including St Paul's Cathedral.

Visit Portland Bill Lighthouse, the striking red and white tower that has guided ships around this dangerous headland since 1906. The lighthouse offers tours revealing the workings of this vital navigational aid, while the surrounding cliffs provide excellent opportunities for birdwatching and coastal photography. The views from Portland Bill extend across Lyme Bay, with the outline of Devon visible on clear days.

Discover Portland Castle, one of England's best-preserved coastal fortresses from the reign of Henry VIII, built in the 1540s to defend against French and Spanish invasion. This artillery castle, with its distinctive rounded walls designed to deflect cannonballs, tells the story of Tudor England's precarious position in European politics. The castle later served as a private residence and now offers fascinating insights into 500 years of English history.

activities.text: Visit Pulpit Rock, the dramatic coastal feature near the lighthouse, and watch the waves crash against the stone platform

days_plan.itin_title: Dorset's Jurassic Wonders: Cliffs, Castles and Coastal Charm

visits.text: Enter the whimsical world of Portmeirion, an enchanting Italianate village on the North Wales coast that feels like a slice of the Amalfi Coast transported to the shores of Snowdonia. Designed by visionary architect Sir Clough Williams-Ellis between 1925 and 1975, this unique village features colorful buildings, campaniles, and piazzas nestled in subtropical gardens cascading to the Dwyryd Estuary. The pastel-painted facades and Mediterranean architecture create an otherworldly atmosphere unlike anywhere else in Britain.

Wander through Portmeirion's labyrinthine paths discovering hidden courtyards, ornate fountains and architectural salvage from across Europe incorporated into Williams-Ellis's grand design. The village gained worldwide fame as the setting for the cult 1960s television series 'The Prisoner,' and fans still visit to explore the iconic locations. Every corner reveals unexpected details, from classical statues to whimsical follies, creating endless opportunities for exploration.

Explore the extensive woodland gardens surrounding the village, where exotic plants thrive in the mild coastal climate created by the Gulf Stream. The wild gardens, planted with rhododendrons, hydrangeas and rare specimens from around the world, offer miles of scenic coastal walks along the estuary. The views across to Snowdonia's peaks provide a stunning backdrop to this unique architectural fantasy.

activities.text: Take a scenic coastal walk through the woodland gardens with views across the estuary to Snowdonia

Photograph Scotland's most iconic castle, Eilean Donan, rising from a small tidal island where three sea lochs meet against a backdrop of misty mountains. This 13th-century fortress, completely restored in the early 20th century, has appeared in countless films and photographs, epitomizing the romance of the Scottish Highlands. The interior reveals grand banqueting halls, bedchambers and a fascinating collection of Jacobite memorabilia.

Cross the bridge to the Isle of Skye, an island of legendary beauty that has captivated visitors for centuries with its dramatic landscapes and mystical atmosphere. The Cuillin mountains, jagged peaks of black gabbro rock, dominate the skyline while sea cliffs, waterfalls and pristine beaches line the coast. Skye's combination of raw natural beauty and Gaelic culture creates an experience unlike anywhere else in Scotland.

Arrive in Portree, Skye's charming capital, where brightly painted buildings line the harbor creating one of Scotland's most photographed scenes. This bustling little town serves as the perfect base for exploring the island, with excellent restaurants, traditional pubs and shops selling local crafts and tweeds. The harbor comes alive with fishing boats and tour vessels offering wildlife cruises around the island's dramatic coastline.

Hike to the Old Man of Storr, Skye's most famous landmark, where a 50-meter pinnacle of rock rises from a tumbled landscape of ancient landslip. The walk through a forest of mossy trees emerges onto open hillside with views across to the mainland and the islands of Raasay and Rona. On a misty morning, the rock formations appear like giants frozen in stone, creating an atmosphere of Celtic mythology come to life.

Marvel at Kilt Rock, a dramatic sea cliff whose columnar basalt formations resemble the pleats of a Scottish kilt, with the Mealt Falls cascading 60 meters directly into the sea below. The viewing platform offers safe vantage points to appreciate this unique geological formation, created by ancient lava flows meeting the sea. The constant sound of the waterfall and the cries of seabirds nesting on the cliffs create a symphony of coastal Scotland.

Explore the Quiraing, an extraordinary landscape of pinnacles, cliffs and hidden plateaus formed by massive landslips on the Trotternish Ridge. The winding road to the Quiraing offers some of Skye's most dramatic views, while hiking trails lead through this otherworldly terrain to the hidden valley known as 'The Table.' This is Skye at its most mysterious and beautiful, a landscape that seems to belong to another world entirely.

Discover the enchanting Fairy Glen near Uig, a miniature landscape of conical hills, spiral paths and mysterious stone circles that legend attributes to the work of fairies. This quirky natural wonder, tucked away from the main tourist routes, offers a gentler taste of Skye's magic with easy walking and endless photographic possibilities. The strange symmetry of the hills and the sense of entering a secret world make this an unforgettable stop.

visits.text: Immerse yourself in the breathtaking landscapes of Snowdonia National Park, home to Wales' highest peaks and most dramatic mountain scenery. The park encompasses 823 square miles of rugged mountains, glacial lakes, ancient forests and wild moorland that has inspired artists, poets and adventurers for centuries. On clear days, the views across the peaks create some of the most spectacular panoramas in Britain.

Challenge yourself on Mount Snowdon, the highest mountain in Wales at 1,085 meters, whose summit can be reached by several hiking trails of varying difficulty or by the famous Snowdon Mountain Railway. The Pyg Track and Miners' Track are popular routes offering stunning views over Glaslyn and Llyn Llydaw, glacial lakes that shimmer like jewels in their mountain bowls. On the summit, on clear days, views extend to Ireland, Scotland and England.

Discover the park's hidden valleys, cascading waterfalls and ancient oak woodlands that create a landscape of endless variety and beauty. Historic slate quarries, their terraces carved into mountainsides, tell the story of the industry that shaped North Wales and exported Welsh slate across the world. The mountain villages, with their stone cottages and Welsh-speaking communities, maintain traditions stretching back centuries.

activities.text: Take the Snowdon Mountain Railway from Llanberis for a scenic ascent to the summit without the hiking effort

visits.text: Marvel at the Eden Project, one of Cornwall's most innovative attractions, where enormous biodome structures house botanical gardens showcasing plant species from around the world. Since opening in 2001, this futuristic complex has captivated visitors with its striking exhibitions, interactive experiences and passionate commitment to environmental education. The massive biomes, built in a reclaimed clay pit, create tropical rainforest and Mediterranean climates under their transparent canopies.

Explore St Austell, an old market town that played an essential role in Cornwall's mining and China Clay industries that once made this region prosperous. Reminders of the town's historic importance can still be spotted throughout the streets, including the bygone Cornwall Coliseum. The St Austell Brewing Company offers tours and tastings of traditional Cornish ales brewed using centuries-old methods.

Wander through the Lost Gardens of Heligan, a hidden gem covering more than 200 acres of restored Victorian gardens and woodlands near Mevagissey. Suspended bridges, moss-covered statues and jungle-like plantings create an atmosphere of rediscovered wonder in these gardens that lay abandoned and overgrown for decades until their restoration began in the 1990s. The story of the gardens' neglect during World War I and subsequent rescue adds poignant historical depth to their natural beauty.

activities.text: Spend a half-day exploring the Eden Project's biomes and outdoor gardens

days_plan.itin_title: Cornwall Coastal Treasures: Castles, Coves and Celtic Heritage

visits.text: Marvel at the Green Bridge of Wales, a spectacular natural limestone arch dramatically jutting into the sea on the Pembrokeshire coast. This remarkable geological formation, carved by millennia of wave action, creates one of Wales' most photographed natural wonders. The nearby Elegug Stacks, two giant pillars of stone rising from the sea, add to this dramatic coastal landscape that showcases the raw power of nature.

Explore St Davids, Britain's smallest city and the most westerly point of Wales, built around its magnificent medieval cathedral. St Davids Cathedral, nestled in a peaceful hollow, is the final resting place of Wales' patron saint and has been a site of pilgrimage for over 1,500 years. The purple-hued stone building with its distinctive square tower represents one of the finest examples of medieval religious architecture in Britain.

Watch a spectacular sunset at Whitesands Beach near St Davids, one of the most stunning coastal experiences in Wales. This beautiful Blue Flag beach offers pristine golden sands backed by dramatic headlands, with views stretching across St Brides Bay. The sunsets here paint the sky in extraordinary colors, creating magical moments that visitors remember long after leaving.

activities.text: Book a boat tour with Thousand Island Expeditions to Skomer Island, home to the largest Atlantic puffin colony in southern Britain

days_plan.itin_title: Welsh Wonders: Castles, Coastlines and Celtic Charm

visits.text: Discover St Ives, perhaps the most beloved destination in Cornwall, where expansive golden beaches stretch beneath a picturesque town of cobbled streets and whitewashed cottages. For centuries, this fishing village has attracted visitors drawn by its exceptional light, beautiful beaches and artistic heritage. The combination of seaside charm, cultural attractions and natural beauty makes St Ives irresistible to first-time visitors and returning devotees alike.

Visit Tate St Ives, the modern art gallery that showcases works by artists who have been inspired by Cornwall's extraordinary light and landscape since the 1920s. The gallery's striking architecture, perched above Porthmeor Beach, provides the perfect setting for collections that include works by Barbara Hepworth, Ben Nicholson and other luminaries of the St Ives School. The views from the gallery windows compete with the art on the walls for visitors' attention.

Explore the winding cobbled streets connecting cute corners, seaside pubs and traditional pasty shops that give St Ives its irresistible character. The harbor, still home to a working fishing fleet, provides a picturesque heart to the town, while the beaches on either side offer different characters for swimming, surfing or simply sunbathing. Boat trips depart regularly to spot dolphins or see the iconic Godrevy Lighthouse up close.

Relax on the beautiful beaches of St Ives, which are particularly impressive at low tide when vast expanses of golden sand are revealed. Porthmeor Beach attracts surfers and art lovers drawn to the nearby Tate, while the sheltered Harbour Beach offers calmer waters for families. The town's position on a narrow peninsula means you're never far from the sound of the waves, wherever you wander.

visits.text: Journey to Brownsea Island, a National Trust nature reserve in the heart of Poole Harbour that is home to one of Britain's few remaining colonies of red squirrels. This 500-acre island of woodland, heathland and lagoons also holds historical significance as the birthplace of the worldwide Scouting movement, where Baden-Powell held his first camp in 1907. Peacocks roam freely among the paths, and the diverse habitats support an abundance of wildlife including sika deer and numerous bird species.

Explore the island's varied landscapes on self-guided walking trails that reveal different ecosystems from pine woodland to sandy beaches. The outdoor center provides information about the wildlife you might encounter, from kingfishers and ospreys to the island's famous red squirrels. The tranquil atmosphere and lack of vehicles create a peaceful escape just minutes from the bustling mainland.

Discover Swanage, a charming Victorian seaside town that evolved from a smugglers' haven into a beloved family holiday destination during the 19th century. The sandy beach, traditional pier and historic town center retain their old-world charm, while boat trips and coastal walks offer modern adventures. The town's quarrying heritage is visible in the stone buildings and monuments that were shipped from here to build some of London's finest structures.

Hike to Old Harry Rocks, the spectacular chalk sea stacks that stand as sentinels at the eastern gateway to the Jurassic Coast. The challenging climb from Swanage rewards hikers with views of these iconic white pillars rising from aquamarine waters, their brilliant surfaces contrasting with the deep blue sea. This UNESCO World Heritage coastline tells the story of 185 million years of Earth's history in its cliffs, rocks and fossils.

Visit Durlston Country Park, just one mile from Swanage, where the historic Great Globe and panoramic coastal views have drawn visitors since Victorian times. This 320-acre park encompasses limestone cliffs, wildflower meadows and wildlife-rich habitats with some of the best views along the Dorset coast. The castle-like Durlston Castle visitor center provides information about the park's geology, wildlife and the fascinating history of the Great Globe monument.

activities.text: Take a self-guided wildlife walk and try to spot the elusive red squirrels that thrive on this protected island

Discover Tenby, a picturesque harbor town in Pembrokeshire whose rows of multi-colored Georgian houses have made it one of Wales' most beloved holiday destinations. The pastel-painted facades cascading down to the golden beaches and bustling harbor create postcard-perfect scenes that have attracted visitors for generations. This charming seaside resort offers the perfect blend of historic character, sandy beaches and traditional Welsh hospitality.

Explore the medieval town walls that still encircle much of Tenby's historic center, offering elevated walks with views over the harbor and out to Caldey Island. The narrow cobbled streets within the walls are lined with independent shops, galleries and restaurants serving fresh local seafood. St Catherine's Island, accessible at low tide, adds a touch of adventure with its Victorian fort perched dramatically above the waves.

Relax on Tenby's beautiful beaches, including the sheltered North Beach and the expansive South Beach backed by dramatic limestone cliffs. The clear blue waters and golden sands rival any Mediterranean resort, yet maintain an authentically Welsh character with traditional beach huts and family-friendly atmosphere. The harbor comes alive with fishing boats and pleasure craft, offering boat trips along the stunning Pembrokeshire coast.

visits.text: Stand among the legendary ruins of Tintagel Castle, perched dramatically on a rugged headland with cliffs plunging to the Atlantic on three sides. While not much remains of the medieval castle itself, the association with King Arthur and the dramatic new footbridge spanning a deep chasm between two impossibly steep cliffs make this one of Cornwall's most unforgettable attractions. The legends claim this as Arthur's birthplace, and the atmosphere of myth and mystery pervades every stone.

Cross the spectacular footbridge that links the mainland to the island portion of Tintagel Castle, a modern engineering marvel that recreates an ancient connection severed by centuries of erosion. The vertiginous walkway offers heart-stopping views down to the waves crashing on rocks far below. Archaeological excavations have revealed that this site was an important settlement during the Dark Ages, lending some historical basis to the Arthurian legends.

Explore Merlin's Cave beneath the castle headland, accessible at low tide via a dramatic sea cave that cuts completely through the promontory. Legend holds that the wizard Merlin lived in this cave and that it was here he first met the infant Arthur. The combination of dramatic natural features and powerful mythology makes Tintagel one of the most evocative historic sites in Britain, drawing visitors who seek both history and legend.

visits.text: Explore Truro, Cornwall's only city, where the magnificent Victorian cathedral with its unusual three spires towers above the historic streets. While urban amenities and cultural offerings exceed those found elsewhere in the region, Truro maintains a distinctly laid-back Cornish character with its independent shops, cafes and the vibrant Lemon Street Market. The city serves as an excellent base for exploring the surrounding area while offering more significant cultural attractions.

Visit the Royal Cornwall Museum to discover the fascinating history of this unique region, from prehistoric times through the tin mining era to the present day. The museum's collections illuminate the distinctive Cornish culture and the Celtic language that sets this peninsula apart from the rest of England. Exhibitions explore the mining heritage that brought prosperity and shaped the landscape, now recognized with UNESCO World Heritage status.

Admire the Cathedral of the Blessed Virgin Mary, a Victorian Gothic masterpiece completed in 1910 that ranks among the finest 19th-century churches in England. The three soaring spires create an unmistakable silhouette above the city, while the interior features beautiful stained glass and impressive stone vaulting. The cathedral's relatively recent construction makes it unusual among England's great churches, most of which date from medieval times.

visits.text: Journey aboard the Talyllyn Railway, the world's first preserved railway, known affectionately as 'The Railway with a Heart of Gold.' This historic steam train, operating since 1865, carries passengers on a scenic 55-minute journey from the coastal town of Tywyn seven miles into the heart of Snowdonia National Park. The gentle pace allows time to absorb the stunning Welsh landscapes, from pastoral valleys to dramatic mountain scenery.

Travel to Nant Gwernol, the railway's terminus deep in a wooded ravine surrounded by ancient oak forests and cascading waterfalls. The narrow-gauge locomotives puff and whistle through countryside that has changed little since Victorian times, creating an authentically nostalgic experience. Walking trails from the station lead to spectacular viewpoints and the atmospheric ruins of old slate quarries.

Explore Tywyn, a traditional Welsh seaside town that serves as the gateway to the Talyllyn Railway and the southern reaches of Snowdonia. The town's long sandy beach stretches for miles, backed by dunes and offering views across Cardigan Bay to the Llŷn Peninsula. St Cadfan's Church houses the Cadfan Stone, bearing the earliest known written Welsh, connecting visitors to 1,400 years of Welsh linguistic heritage.

activities.text: Hike from Nant Gwernol station through the forest to discover hidden waterfalls and old quarry workings

Village walk and viewpoints over Loch Broom

Explore Ullapool, a picturesque fishing village established in 1788 as a herring port, whose whitewashed cottages line the shores of Loch Broom against a backdrop of towering mountains. This charming town serves as the gateway to the Summer Isles and the wild northwest coast, with ferries departing for the Outer Hebrides. The harbor bustles with fishing boats and pleasure craft, while the main street offers excellent seafood restaurants, craft shops and traditional pubs.

Take a boat trip to the Summer Isles, an archipelago of uninhabited islands scattered across the mouth of Loch Broom. These emerald gems offer opportunities for seal watching, seabird spotting and landing on pristine beaches where you might be the only visitors. The views back to the mainland reveal the full majesty of the Assynt mountains rising from the coast.

Drive the spectacular Drumbeg Road, one of the most scenic stretches of the North Coast 500, winding through a landscape of rocky knolls, hidden lochs and dramatic coastal views. This single-track road with passing places epitomizes the adventure of driving in the Scottish Highlands, where every bend reveals a new vista more stunning than the last. Keep your eyes open for Highland cattle, red deer and golden eagles along this unforgettable route.

visits.text: Marvel at Durdle Door, the iconic natural limestone arch that has become the symbol of the Jurassic Coast and one of England's most photographed landmarks. This spectacular geological formation, created over millions of years as the sea eroded the Portland limestone, frames turquoise waters that rival any Mediterranean cove. The dramatic cliffside setting and crystal-clear waters draw visitors year-round, though the beach is most magical outside peak summer season.

Explore Lulworth Cove, a almost perfectly circular bay that is considered one of the finest examples of coastal erosion in the world and a premier destination for geology enthusiasts. The unique formation occurred as the sea breached the harder Portland limestone and then eroded the softer rocks behind, creating this remarkable natural amphitheater. The Fossil Forest on the cliff path reveals petrified tree stumps from ancient forests that grew here 150 million years ago.

Walk the spectacular coastal path connecting Lulworth Cove to Durdle Door, one of the most scenic short hikes in all of England. The route crosses dramatic chalk cliffs with ever-changing views of the turquoise waters and rocky coastline below. This stretch of the Jurassic Coast reveals layers of geological history spanning 185 million years, visible in the multi-colored cliff faces and embedded fossils.

activities.text: Try coasteering, rock-pooling or swimming in the crystal-clear waters of this UNESCO World Heritage coastline

visits.text: Fall in love with Weymouth, a traditional seaside town whose Georgian esplanade and golden sands have made it one of Britain's most popular holiday destinations for over two centuries. The colorful houses lining the harbor, their doors decorated with nautical knockers, create a quintessentially English coastal scene. The shallow, gently shelving beach and calm waters make this an ideal destination for families and swimmers of all abilities.

Stroll along Weymouth's historic harbor, where boats and yachts bob at their moorings and fresh seafood restaurants serve the day's catch. The old town's narrow streets reveal Georgian architecture and maritime heritage at every turn, from the harbor-side fish market to the Tudor-era waterfront buildings. The working harbor atmosphere, with fishermen mending nets and boats preparing to sail, connects visitors to Weymouth's enduring maritime traditions.

Walk along Chesil Beach, the remarkable 18-mile shingle bank connecting Portland to the Dorset mainland that is one of Britain's most distinctive coastal features. This vast barrier beach, accumulated over thousands of years, grades from small pebbles in the west to large cobbles in the east, a natural phenomenon that allowed local fishermen to determine their position in fog simply by the size of the stones. The Fleet lagoon behind the beach supports rare wildlife and offers peaceful walking away from the crowds.

activities.text: Sample fresh Dorset seafood, including the local specialty mackerel, at one of the harbor-side establishments

visits.text: Hong Kong: British port in the Far East, a key stopover between India and Japan in Fogg's journey.
Commercial districts and quays: managing maritime connections and tensions surrounding possible delays on the itinerary.

activities.text: Retracing Fogg's steps through London by measuring the contrast between the fixity of the city and the movement of the journey accomplished.

visits.text: Calcutta (Kolkata): eventful arrival after an interrupted journey, major colonial city of the British empire in India.
Administrative districts and Hooghly quays: formalities, embarkation and organization of the rest of the journey to Hong Kong.

activities.text: Traverse hills and quays to follow Fogg's trail at the moment when the wager still seems feasible.
Exploring Manhattan between emerging skyscrapers, docks and neighborhoods in full transformation of the late 19th century.

visits.text: Bombay (Mumbai): Fogg and Passepartout's first major immersion in the Indian subcontinent, between colonial station, crowded streets and bustling docks.
Chhatrapati Shivaji Station (inspired by the great colonial stations): departure inland by train toward Calcutta.

activities.text: Gain elevation on Victoria Peak to understand the city's strategic position between the South China Sea and hills.
Discover the contrast between traditional Japan and Western influences in a major port of the emerging Meiji era.

visits.text: Yokohama: major gateway to Japan opened to the West, where Fogg and Passepartout manage at the last minute to embark for America.
Entertainment districts and bustling streets: Passepartout's wanderings after being separated from Fogg.

activities.text: Discover the contrast between traditional Japan and Western influences in a major port of the emerging Meiji era.

visits.text: New York: major metropolis of the East Coast where Fogg arrives late, forced to find an alternative solution to reach Europe.
Port of New York: negotiations and improvisations around a cargo ship to cross the Atlantic urgently.

activities.text: Exploring Manhattan between emerging skyscrapers, docks and neighborhoods in full transformation of the late 19th century.

visits.text: San Francisco: arrival in North America, a booming city where Fogg must quickly organize the crossing of the continent.
Waterfront and dock district: piers and nearby stations that symbolize the junction between sea and rail.
